Description: Wheel-made ring oil-lamp with a low-placed carination, and a broard, inward-sloping rim. Big, circular filling-hole. Short nozzle. The oil-lamp stands on a flat resting-surface. Red-brown (Nile silt?) fabric. Red slipped surface. Nozzle blackened by smoke and chipped.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Unprovenanced parallel from Egypt, dated from the 6th to 5th century BC or 'considerably later' (Bailey 1975, British Museum Lamps I, Q514).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KC.19) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4842 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
